p: From our results, latter (RT-PCR) also demonstrated to have high sensitivity and specificity threshold ( Medina et al., 2015, Zink et al., 2015, Tappe et al., 2015a, Zammarchi et al., 2015a, Lanciotti et al., 2008). Though the techniques have not been widely used in the African context as compared to Europe, USA and Asia, applicability and viability has been partially assessed in Africa in varying scenarios ( Gasque et al., 2015, Blair and Olson, 2015, Kleinman, 2015, Faye et al., 2013). Nonetheless, the approaches have adhered to robust methodologies with the capacity to inform on cues of averting cross-reactions for instance mis-diagnosis between dengue and Zika virus subtypes ( Diagne et al., 2015, Ginier et al., 2016, Musso et al., 2015a, Peterhans et al., 1999, Kleinman, 2015, Zammarchi et al., 2015a, Faye et al., 2013, Lanciotti et al., 2008). Three techniques have been used broadly; indirect immunofluorescence assay (IIFA), Enzyme linked immunosorbent Assay (ELISA) and RT-PCR or next generation sequencing (NGS) ( Kean et al., 2015, Musso et al., 2015a, Papa et al., 2015, Robin and Mouchet, 1974, Tappe et al., 2015b, Weaver and Forrester, 2015, Haddow et al., 2012, Pyke et al., 2014, Faye et al., 2013). Multiparameter flow cytometry has had marginal application yielding less insightful results between the cases and controls ( Weaver and Forrester, 2015, Peterhans et al., 1999, Zammarchi et al., 2015a).
